title: This is why fat blokes are ‘BETTER in bed’ – and surprisingly it’s down to stamina
text:
Click to share on Facebook (Opens in new window) Comments THERE is a surprising bonus to being overweight – men are more likely to last longer between the sheets, experts say. 
The average time before a man climaxes is said to be about five and a half minutes, but in a recent study men with a higher body mass index have more stamina than that. Alamy 2 Men with a larger waistline are more likely to last longer between the sheets, doctors discovered 
Premature ejaculation is the most frequently reported sexual problem among men, according to the Erciyes University in Turkey study. 
It is defined as ejaculating before, or within a minute of vaginal penetration and the inability to delay the climax. 
For many men who suffer this affliction, it can cause distress and eventually lead to them avoiding sexual intimacy. 
But, doctors have discovered that men who reported suffering from premature ejaculation actually had a leaner BMI than those who didn’t. 
The UK is facing an obesity epidemic, with heart disease the biggest killer in the country causing about 74,000 deaths each year. 
That’s the equivalent of 200 people dying everyday from the obesity related disease. 
Other side effects of being overweight include high blood pressure, type 2 diabetes and an increased risk of stroke. Getty Images Men who are leaner were more likely to suffer premature ejaculation 
The message from doctors nation-wide is that something needs to change. 
And while obesity is associated with erectile dysfunction , it is not associated with premature ejaculation (PE). 
In the study , more than 200 men were asked how long it took them to ejaculate. 
They were then placed into two groups – a premature ejaculation group and a control group. 
Researchers found the number of obese men in the control group, those who lasted longer in the bedroom, was three times higher that the group prone to premature ejaculation. 
Furthermore, the number of men in the premature ejaculation group who were a normal weight but climaxed within a minute was two times higher. The researchers concluded: “We found that patients with lifelong premature ejaculation were leaner than the healthy control cases and the number of the patients decreased as their BMI increased. 
“In addition, the prevalence of obesity was lower in the premature ejaculation group than in the control group. 
“This is the first prospective study that investigated the relationship between lifelong premature ejaculation and obesity. 
“Although we know that our study may not directly affect patient care, these findings may be useful in understanding the physiopathology of lifelong premature ejaculation.” 
As for why this might be? 
Researchers believe that overweight men may have higher levels of the female sex hormone, oestradiol, which can inhibit the male orgasm. 
They also believe a decreased level of serotonin – the happiness hormone – is involved in delaying ejaculation.
